Dear Ms. Allen-Pettway:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
11/08/2019. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the ISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and
rules except for the following:
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report
required by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar days of its
completion.
One out of four licensing records reviewed contained late verification of the special
evaluation report being sent to the foster parent by 24 days.
R 400.12404 Placement.
(7) An agency shall document, in the child's record, within 7
calendar days after placement, the information specified in R
400.12417(1) and all of the following information:
(h) A photograph of the child at the time of placement.
Two out of eight applicable foster care records reviewed contained photos of the
child two and five months after placement.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
One out of eight applicable foster care records reviewed contained a late initial
service plan by two days.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Two out of eight foster care records reviewed contained one late updated service
plan each by four and 15 days.
4

2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the
following:
ISEP 6.18 Page Relative Foster Parent Licensing, Timeliness (Commitment
23 54).
DHHS must license at least 85% of newly licensed relative
foster parents within 180 days of the date of placement.
The agency has 13 relative foster parent homes pending licensure that have been
over 180-days. Three relative homes are pending denials, one is being withdrawn,
one requesting a waiver, four are pending review, two requiring addendums,
whereas two continue to wait on submitting paperwork and making updates to home.
REPEAT CITATION FROM INTERIM 12/07/2018 INSPECTION REPORT
ISEP 6.30 Page Supervisory Oversight (Commitment 66).
27
Supervisors shall meet at least monthly with each assigned
worker to review the status and progress of each case on the
worker’s caseload. Supervisors shall review and approve each
service plan. The plan can be approved only after the supervisor
has a face-to-face meeting with the worker, which can be the
monthly meeting.
One out of eight foster care records reviewed did not contain documentation of
monthly supervisory face-to-face meetings for 04/2019 and 05/2019.
REPEAT CITATION FROM INTERIM 12/07/2018 INSPECTION REPORT

Page 11-12
Siblings in foster care, who are not placed together, must have
at least one visit per calendar month that is in addition to
parenting time.
Three out of eight applicable foster care records reviewed were deficient with sibling
visits occurring. The first and second case records did not contain three sibling visits
occurring over two report periods, whereas the third case record did not contain five
sibling visits over three report periods.
DHHS Policy Intent to Adopt Form

whom the child is placed that the child’s permanency plan is
adoption. The caregiver’s interest in adoption must be
documented.
One out of six applicable adoption case records reviewed did not contain verification
of the worker notifying the foster parent within three days that the child’s
permanency plan changed to adoption.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(c) Conduct a thorough investigation including all necessary
collateral contacts.
7

In one special evaluation reviewed the cleanliness of the foster home was alleged to
be in question. The report did not contain the worker’s description of the home’s
cleanliness, rather the report only used the complainant’s allegations. It is
recommended that special evaluations contain a description of the home’s
cleanliness by the worker noted at time of the home visit, and preferably,
unannounced.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information:
(e) Findings of fact, based upon the evaluation.
In one special evaluation reviewed, behavior management and foster parent duties
were alleged to be non-compliant. Foster child’s interview was noted under foster
the parent duties section of the report, whereas it should have also been addressed
in both alleged non-compliant areas.
DHHS Policy Required Participation in Development - Foster Parent /
FOM 722-08C Caregiver
Page 2
The foster parent/caregiver signature is required and indicates
that the foster parent/caregiver acknowledges and agrees to the
activities required to meet the needs of the child in their care.
Three foster care records reviewed contained foster parent signatures but did not
contain signature dates. Case managers need to assure that foster parents date
their signatures.
8

V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information:
(f) Conclusions regarding licensing rules compliance or
noncompliance based on the findings of fact.
One special evaluation contained a Foster Home Compliance Record (DHHS 3080)
that contained the foster parent signature dated 09/09/2019, whereas the worker
signed the form on 09/20/2019 along with the corrective action plan. Best practice is
to only have a foster parent sign forms without later modifying it.
R 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a written
adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family signing an
adoption application and prior to approving a family for adoption.
The domestic adoption program utilizes a two-step application process for adoptive
families. A notice of interest with deposit is first obtained, which the agency calls an
“Application”. It is noted that the deposit is partially refundable if the adoptive family
decides not to further pursue the adoption home study process. Once the adoptive
family provides the agency with required documentation, the family signs a
“Contract” which outlines the agreement between the adoptive parents and agency.
For the purpose of child welfare licensing, the agency’s “Contract” with the adoptive
family serves as the application pertaining to the requirements of this rule. The
agency must include the “Contract” signature date on the adoptive family home
study to determine the 90-day start date.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. The facility cited the foster parent as noncompliant and successfully
completed a corrective action plan to include additional training.
The agency submitted two acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
A corrective action plan was submitted for SIR#2018C0219060 initiated on
07/08/2019 regarding special evaluations verbal summary, report being completed
9

within 15 days, appropriateness of licensing recommendation, and special
evaluation initiation. The CAP appears to have been successful.
A corrective action plan was submitted for the 12/07/2018 interim inspection. It
successfully addressed the following as no repeat citations are noted: Special
evaluation extension letter, special evaluation verbal summary, special evaluation
completed within 15 days, case manager given a copy of special evaluation and
CAP, late initial medical exam, adoptive evaluation given to parents, and contact
with birth parent within 30 days. Repeat citations include the following: Relatives
being licensed within 180 days, quarterly medical passports, supervisor meeting with
worker before signing service plan, and foster parent involvement in FTM’s.
Analyst safety concern form dated 09/11/2019 indicated one foster home having
purchased a carbon monoxide detector though was not installed at time of the home
visit. The agency conducted a home visit on 09/24/2019 and determined that the
carbon monoxide detector was installed and operable.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
